get.summary: List Audit Entries for an API Proxy
get.description: Lists audit records for management operations for an API proxy in an organization. For API proxy revisions, deploy and undeploy actions are recorded as `CREATE` operations. You can distinguish between them by examining the `requestUri` element in the output. For every call made to the management API, Apigee Edge logs an audit record. This API enables you to obtain a record of all management calls made against API proxies in an organization. The audit logs provide access to the actions (create, read, update, delete) executed on organizations. If there are no audit records, or if the entity does not exist, this API returns an empty array. If you omit the `timeline`, `startTime`, and `endTime` query parameters, the default is to use `timeline=today`.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: `true` - Returns all of the audit results from the specified API proxy entity and all of its sub-entities, including revisions, policies, resources, etc. `false` (default) - Only returns results for the specified API proxy entity (where the query URI is an exact match). Records for "sub-entities" including revisions, policies, resources, etc, are excluded. Note: With `expand=false`, you can also ask for a specific "sub-entity", such as a specific revision. For example: `/apis/apiname/revisions/2`

get.summary: Subscribe or Unsubscribe from Analytics Report
get.description: Organization administrators can subscribe to daily analytics summary reports sent through email. You can use this API to subscribe to (optin=true) or unsubscribe from (optin=false) daily analytics reports. You can also subscribe/unsubscribe in the management UI by selecting **your username > User Settings**, then selecting/deselecting **Receive daily analytics summary report**. For more information, see [Subscribe to daily analytics emails](/analytics-services/content/subscribe-daily-analytics-emails).

post.summary: Create a Vault Entry in an Environment
post.description: Creates an entry with a specific name and secure value in a vault in a specified environment. For key information about the appropriate use of vaults as secure storage, see [Using the secure store](/docs/api-services/content/using-secure-store).

**Edge on-premises installation only. For an Edge cloud installation, contact** [Apigee Customer Support](http://community.apigee.com/content/apigee-customer-support).
After you create an environment, by using [Create Environment](/management/apis/post/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments), you have to enable analytics for the environment.  If you enable analytics for one environment in an organization, you must enable analytics for all environments in the organization.  **Note:** This call requires that you pass a file named sample.json that contains entries for Analytics onboarding. The sample.json file contains the following: 
{
  "properties" : {
    "samplingAlgo" : "reservoir_sampler",
    "samplingTables" : "10=ten;1=one;",
    "aggregationinterval" : "300000",
    "samplingInterval" : "300000",
    "useSampling" : "100",
    "samplingThreshold" : "100000"
  },
  "servers" : {
    "**postgres-server**" : [ "1acff3a5-8a6a-4097-8d26-d0886853239c", "f93367f7-edc8-4d55-92c1-2fba61ccc4ab" ],  
    "**qpid-server**" : [ "d3c5acf0-f88a-478e-948d-6f3094f12e3b", "74f67bf2-86b2-44b7-a3d9-41ff117475dd"] 
  }
}
The postgres-servers property contains a comma-separated list of the Postgres UUIDs, and the qpid-server property contains the Qpid UUIDs. If you need to obtain these UUIDs, use the following commands. For Qpid, run the command: 
curl -u : http:///v1/servers?pod=central
The output of this command is a JSON object. For each Qpid server, you will see output in the form: 
"type" : [ "qpid-server" ],
"uUID" : "d3c5acf0-f88a-478e-948d-6f3094f12e3b"
For Postgres, run the command: 
curl -u : http:///v1/servers?pod=analytics
For each Postgres server, you will see output in the form: 
"type" : [ "postgres-server" ],
"uUID" : "d3c5acf0-f88a-478e-948d-6f3094f12e3b"
If you are using Edge for Private Cloud 4.16.01 or later, rather than use the API call, use the following command to enable Analytics: 
> //apigee/apigee-service/bin/apigee-service apigee-provision enable-ax -f _**configFile**_
Where _**configFile**_ contains: 
ORG_NAME=orgName  # lowercase only, no spaces, underscores, or periods.
ENV_NAME=envName

delete.summary: Delete a Vault in an Environment
delete.description: Deletes an entire vault in a specified environment. For key information about the appropriate use of vaults as secure storage, see [Using the secure store](/docs/api-services/content/using-secure-store).

get.summary: Get List of Entries in a Vault in an Environment
get.description: Gets a list of entries in a vault in a specified environment. This will not retrieve the encrypted values of the entries. For key information about the appropriate use of vaults as secure storage, see [Using the secure store](/docs/api-services/content/using-secure-store).

get.summary: List Audit Entries for a Developer App
get.description: Lists audit records for management operations for a developer app. For every call made to the management API, Apigee Edge logs an audit record. This API enables you to obtain a record of all management calls made against apps in an organization. The audit logs provide access to the actions (create, read, update, delete) executed on the apps. If there are no audit records, or if the entity does not exist, this API returns an empty array. If you omit the `timeline`, `startTime`, and `endTime` query parameters, the default is to use `timeline=today`.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: Set expand as `true` to expand the audit records to return all audit records for the app.

get.description:
Use this API call to get the number of API messages made per time intervat in an organization and environment. **If you have multiple organizations and environments**, make this API call for each one and add them to get the total number of calls per time interval for your API program.
To convert the JSON response to a CSV format for use in spreadsheets, use a tool like [https://json-csv.com/](https://json-csv.com/)
For different and more granular metrics, use the [Get metrics for a dimension](/management/apis/get/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D/stats/%7Bdimension_name%7D-0) management API. For more information on the analytics management API, see [Use the analytics API to measure API program performance](/analytics-services/content/use-analytics-api-measure-api-program-performance).

get.summary: Gets npm dependencies for an API Proxy.
get.description: Gets npm dependencies for an API Proxy.

post.description: Runs a specified `npm` command for an API proxy deployed on Apigee Edge. When you call this API, it is equivalent to executing an `npm` command in the `resources/node` directory of the API proxy. Valid `npm` commands that you can execute with this API are: * install * update  * outdated  * dedupe  * prune  * ls (default if no query param is specified) **Usage:** Specify the body of this API like this: "command={npm-command}". For example: `command=install`. The command is designed to install known dependencies for the API's package directory (resources/node). Do not try to specify an arbitrary published Node.js package name with this API. For example, something like this will fail: `command=install async`. With the exception of `ls` and `outdated`, all of these commands replace `node_modules.zip` and any other ZIP file in `resources/node` with the prefix `node_modules` with a new set of files that contains the updated dependencies. For details about these individual `npm` commands, see https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/. **Example 1:** `command=ls` Returns a list of Node.js dependencies.  **Example 2:** `command=install` Installs all dependencies for the `resources/node` directory.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: If `true`, the output will include additional information from npm on which API calls were made to the registry.

get.summary: List Audit Entries for an Organization
get.description: Lists audit records for management operations for an organization. For API proxy revisions, deploy and undeploy actions are recorded as `CREATE` operations. You can distinguish between them by examining the `requestUri` element in the output. For every call made to the management API, Apigee Edge logs an audit record. This API enables you to obtain a record of all management calls made against entities in an organization. The audit logs provide access to the actions (create, read, update, delete) executed on organizations. If there are no audit records, this API returns an empty array. If you omit the `timeline`, `startTime`, and `endTime` query parameters, the default is to use `timeline=today`.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: Set expand as `true` to expand the audit records to return records for the org and all entities in the org. If set to `false` then the API only returns records for the org.

get.description: Gets the names of all environments in an organization. By default, an Apigee organization contains two environments: test and prod.

post.description:
**Edge on-premises installation only. For an Edge cloud installation, contact** [Apigee Customer Support](http://community.apigee.com/content/apigee-customer-support).
Creates an environment in an existing organization.  **Note**: The characters you can use in the **name** attribute are restricted to: a-zA-Z0-9._\-$ %.  After you create the environment, you must: * Associate the environment with one or more Message processors. See [Associate an environment with a Message Processor](/management/apis/post/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D/servers). * Enable analytics on the environment. See [Enable analytics for an environment](/management/apis/post/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D/analytics/admin). Edge provides scripts and other tools that you can use as an alternative to making API calls directly. See the Edge _Operations Guide_ for more information on these tools. For example, for Edge 4.16.05 and later, see [http://docs.apigee.com/api-services/latest/creating-organization-environment-and-virtual-host](/api-services/latest/creating-organization-environment-and-virtual-host).

name.description: The name of the environment. Characters you can use in the name are restricted to: `a-zA-Z0-9._\-$ %`.

properties.description: Name/value pairs that may be used for customizing the environment.

get.summary: Get OAuth 1.0 Access Tokens Count for a Developer App Key
get.description: Get count of OAuth 1.0 access tokens for a developer's app key.

post.summary: Disassociate an environment with a Message Processor
post.description:
**Edge on-premises installation only. For an Edge cloud installation, contact** [Apigee Customer Support](http://community.apigee.com/content/apigee-customer-support).
Before you can delete an environment, see [Delete an environment](/management/apis/delete/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D), you must disassociate it with all Message Processors. You must call this API for each Message Processor associated with the environment.   To determine the list of Message Processor UUIDs associate with the environment, use [Get servers associated with an environment](/management/apis/get/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D/servers). The request body must contain: 
action=remove&uuid={_**MP_UUID**_}
where _**MP_UUID**_ is the UUID of the Message Processor. For example, in a cURL command, the request would appear as: 
curl -H "Content-Type:application/x-www-form-urlencoded" -u _**sysAdminEmail:pWord**_ -X POST http://<_**MS_IP**_>:8080/v1/organizations/{org_name}/environments/{env_name}/servers -d "action=remove&uuid=_**MP_UUID**_"
where _**MS_IP**_ is the IP address or DNS name of the Edge Management Server.

uuid.description: The UUID of the Message Processor.

get.summary: Get servers associated with an environment
get.description:
**Edge on-premises installation only. For an Edge cloud installation, contact** [Apigee Customer Support](http://community.apigee.com/content/apigee-customer-support).
Before you can delete an environment, see [Delete an environment](/management/apis/delete/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D), you must disassociate it with all Message Processors. Use this API to determine the UUIDs of the Message Processors associated with the environment.
Gets a list of apps in an app family for a developer.

post.description: Updates an existing app family to change its name or the list of apps in the family. You must specify the entire request object, including the `name` property and `apps` property.

name.description: App family to which developer apps will be added.

apps.description: Name of developer app to add to app family. An App can only be a associated with one app family.

delete.description: Deletes a developer's app family. The apps in the family are not affected.

get.description: Retrieves a list of transaction IDs for a debug session that was created by the Create Debug Session API call or by the Trace tool in the Edge management UI. Each item in the returned list is the unique ID for a debug session transaction associated with a single request to the API proxy specified. Use the "Get debug session transaction data" API to retrieve the raw debug data for the transaction.
Lists all developers associated with a company.

post.description: Adds a developer to a company, or updates an existing developer in the company. When updating an existing developer, specify both the developer's email and role.

email.description: The unique ID for a company developer

role.description: An entry that may be used for access control to app information by a client, but which is not enforced by Apigee

post.description:
Updates or creates app attributes. This API replaces the current list of attributes with the attributes specified in the request body. This lets you update existing attributes, add new attributes, or delete existing attributes by omitting them from the request body.
**CPS**: With [Core Persistence Services](/api-services/content/api-reference-getting-started#cps), the custom attribute limit is 18.

get.description: Returns a list of all app attributes.

get.description: Returns a count of all 1.0a access tokens in an organization.

delete.description: Removes an app from a developer's app family. An app family requires at least one app. Therefore, removing all apps from an app family also deletes the app family.

post.description:
Clears a cache entry, which is identified by the full CacheKey prefix and value. For more on cache keys, see [Working with cache keys](/docs/api-services/reference/working-cachekeys). To learn how to clear a cache using policies, see [Example: General purpose caching](/docs/api-services/reference/optimize-performance-using-cache). To use the API call, specify the complete **CacheKey** (any Prefix and KeyFragments) and the value of the entry that you want to clear. For example, for the following Cache entry: 
apifactory__test__cacheforecast__8__default__12797282
Clear with the following: 
https://api.enterprise.apigee.com/v1/o/apifactory/e/test/caches/cacheforecast/entries/
apifactory__test__cacheforecast__8__default__1279728?"action=clear
CacheKey is specified in the Cache or Response Cache policy responsible for interacting with the specified Cache resource.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: Specifies the action to take against the entry in the specified cache. The only valid value is 'clear'.

delete.description: Remove an app from a company app family.

post.description:
**Edge on-premises installation only. For an Edge cloud installation, contact** [Apigee Customer Support](http://community.apigee.com/content/apigee-customer-support).
Creates a global user. See [About global users](/api-services/content/about-global-users) for more on Edge users, user types, and user roles.  You must pass all information to the call, including first name, last name, email address, and password. After you create the user in an organization, you must assign the user to a role in an organization. Roles determine the access rights of the user on Edge. See [Add a user to a role](/management/apis/post/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/userroles/%7Brole_name%7D/users-0) for more.
The user cannot log in to the Edge UI, and does not appear in the list of users in the Edge UI, until you assign it to a role in an organization.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: Specify the content type as application/json or application/xml.

firstName.description: The first name of the new user.

lastName.description: The last name of the new user.

password.description: The password for the new user. The user enters this password to log in to the Edge UI.

emailId.description: The email address of the new user.

get.description:
**Edge on-premises installation only. For an Edge cloud installation, contact** [Apigee Customer Support](http://community.apigee.com/content/apigee-customer-support).
Returns a list of all global users. See [About global users](/api-services/content/about-global-users) for more on Edge users, user types, and user roles.
List all TargetServers in an environment.
List all debug sessions created by the Create Debug Session APi call or by the Trace tool in the Edge management UI.

post.description: Create a debug session. A debug session records detailed information on messages, the Flow processing, and policy execution during processing by an API proxy. The data returned in the debug session is a single XML or JSON representation of all debug data for each message exchange. The debug data is the same as that used to generate the 'Trace' view in the edge management UI. A debug session captures a maximum of 20 messages, or records, for a maximum for 2 minutes (by default), whichever comes first. Debugging involves the following steps: 1\. Start a debug session by creating a debug session. 2\. Send a message for that deployed API proxy. 3\. Retrieve the debug data associated with the debug session. The data can be fetched by issuing a GET call on the session. 4\. Close the debug session. (Closing the debug session discards all the associated data). Alternatively, you can create a debug session that captures only API calls with specific query parameters and/or HTTP headers. Filtering is particularly useful for troubleshooting. For more information, see [Create a debug session with a filter](/management/apis/post/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D/apis/%7Bapi_name%7D/revisions/%7Brevision_number%7D/debugsessions%3F%7Bfilter%7D).

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: The user-given name of the debug session (used to retrieve the results after debugging completes).

post.description:
**Edge on-premises installation only. For an Edge cloud installation, contact** [Apigee Customer Support](http://community.apigee.com/content/apigee-customer-support).
Unlocks a global user. See [About global users](/api-services/content/about-global-users) for more on Edge users, user types, and user roles.  A user’s account may be locked due to attributes set in the password policy. A user with the sysadmin Apigee role assigned can use this API to unlock the user’s account.

post.summary: Create a debug session with a filter
post.description:
Create a debug session that captures specific API calls. This API is an alternative to the basic debug session creation described at [Create a debug session](/management/apis/post/organizations/%7Borg_name%7D/environments/%7Benv_name%7D/apis/%7Bapi_name%7D/revisions/%7Brevision_number%7D/debugsessions). With this API, you can set a filter that captures only API calls that have specific query parameters and/or HTTP headers. For example, if you wanted to capture only API calls with an `Accept: application/json` header, you'd create a debug session with that filter. Filtering API calls in a debug session is particularly useful for root-case analysis to target specific calls that may be causing problems. The filter is set using query parameters on this API call, in the `{filter}` portion of the URL. The query parameters begin with either `header_` or `qparam_` to indicate a header or query parameter. For example: * `**header_**_name=value_`: Captures only calls that contain the specific header and value. Header name and value must be URL encoded. For example: `header_Accept=application%2Fjson` * `**qparam_**_name=value_`: Captures only calls that contain the specific query parameter and value. Query parameter name and value must be URL encoded. For example: `qparam_user=john%20doe` If you use **multiple** headers and/or query parameters in the filter, all conditions must be met in order for API call to be captured. Here's how the previous two examples would be combined into a single filter: header_Accept=application%2Fjson&qparam_user=john%20doe
The filter query parameters in the API call are combined with the query parameters you set in the fields below.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: The user-given name of the debug session (used to retrieve the results after debugging completes).

post.summary: Create a cache in an environment
post.description: Creates a cache in an environment. Caches are created per environment. For data segregation, a cache created in 'test', for example, cannot be accessed by API proxies deployed in 'prod'. The JSON object in the request body can be empty, or the `` tag in XML can be empty, to create a cache with the default settings.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: Enter the name of the cache to create. Characters you can use in the name are restricted to: `A-Z0-9._\-$ %`.

description.description: A description of the cache resource.

diskSizeInMB.description: Deprecated -- will be removed in the future. Specifies the disk space used for the cache, in megabytes.

expirySettings.description: Enables different expiration mechanisms to be applied to entries in the cache. Cache entries can be expired a certain number of seconds after creation, at a specific time of day each day, or on a specific date. Options include: * `timeoutInSec` * `timeOfDay (hh:mm:ss)` * `expiryDate (mm-dd-yyyy)` The Populate Cache policy also lets you set expiry settings. The `valuesNull` property controls which expiry settings are applied for each entry. * If `valuesNull` is false (default), expiry settings in the Populate Cache policy are used. * If `valuesNull` = true, expiry settings in the policy are ignored.

maxElementsInMemory.description: Deprecated -- will be removed in the future. Maximum number of entries the cache keeps in memory. Upon reaching the max limit the entries are evicted using the LRU algorithm.

maxElementsOnDisk.description: Deprecated -- will be removed in the future. Maximum number of entries kept on disk. Upon reaching the max limit the entries are evicted using the LRU algorithm.

inMemorySizeInKB.description: Deprecated -- will be removed in the future. All entries larger than the configured setting size, in kilobytes, will be compressed before being cached.

compression.description: Deprecated -- will be removed in the future. If specified, enables you to configure the size threshold above which cache entries will be compressed. If not specified, compression is disabled. Options include: * minimumSizeInKB: All entries larger than the configured setting size, in kilobytes, will be compressed before being cached.

overflowToDisk.description: Specifies to overflow the in-memory cache to disk.

skipCacheIfElementSizeInKBExceeds.description: If specified, enables you to configure the maximum size of data to be cached. Specify the size limit, in kilobytes, for cache entries. Data larger than the limit you set will not be cached.

get.description: List caches in an environment.
